results.title: The Last of the Mohicans (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Michael Mann, Hunt Lowry and Morgan Creek
results.brief_description: Daniel Day-Lewis and Madeleine Stowe star in this adaptation of James Fenimore Cooper’s classic tale of a white man raised by Mohicans and who becomes embroiled in a clash between two strong and rival nations. Set in the American colonies during the bitter Anglo-French war of 1757, Daniel Day-Lewis as Hawkeye brings strength and passion to the role. This film is typical of the epic romantic sagas with its fast action, breathtaking scenery, spectacular battle scenes and a superb cast.

results.title: The Last of the Mohicans
results.creator_credit: Michael Mann, Hunt Lowry and Morgan Creek
results.brief_description: Set in the American colonies during the brutal Anglo-French war of 1757, this fierce romantic adventure chronicles the story of Hawkeye (Daniel Day-Lewis), a whiteman raised by Mohicans, wo becomes entangled in a raging battle between the two rival nations. Exhilarating and exciting, this is adventure on a grand scale, with heart-stopping action, sizzling romance (between Day-Lewis and Madeleine Stowe) and spectacular battle scenes. An epic tale of love and loyalty, this is great entertainment and should not be missed.

results.title: The Last Metro = Le Derniere Metro
results.creator_credit: Francois Truffaut, SFP, S A -TF1, SEDIF and Les Films Carrosse
results.brief_description: It is Paris, 1942, under the German Occupation, and successful Jewish theatrical director, Lucas Steiner, is forced into hiding. He entrusts the running of the theatre to his wife Marion, who must contend with Daxiat, a pro-Nazi critic. Masterful direction by Truffaut captures the climate of the occupation.

results.title: The Last meow: 'Valse Triste', Jean Sibelius
results.brief_description: Excerpt from “Allegro Non Troppo” by Bruno Bozzetto with music by Jean Sibelius. A scrawny cat prowls the crumbling ruins of a house, remembering the warmth and snugness of family life he once enjoyed. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Last marsh
results.brief_description: A photographic record of one of the last great urban marshes, the Powderhorn Marsh, filled in 1968 to constitute an urban intersection in Chicago. The destruction of the marsh raises many ecological questions. Must encroaching urbanisation continue to disrupt natural wildlife preserves?

results.title: The Last klezmer: Leopold Kozlowski, his life and music [NTSC]
results.brief_description: A wedding without a klezmer was worse than a funeral without tears according to the opening quote of this documentary film. “Klezmer” music is Jewish music, music which comes from the mind and soul of the Jewish people, music which can be happy, tragic, reflect the history of the Jews, of pogroms and inquisitions, and of being Yiddish. Klezmer musicians are born, not made, and this rich cultural tradition which originated in pre-World War II Poland and almost disappeared during the second World War because of the Holocaust and the Jewish migration out of Europe, has gone through a revival in America, particularly in New York. Leopold Kozlowski is one of the last remaining original klezmer musicians trained in the prewar tradition and through this documentary film, we journey with Leopold into his sometimes painful and tragic past to discover the inspiring and vibrant Jewish culture which he is so desperately trying to keep alive in Poland. Born in a small village near Lvov (Poland) called Przemyslany (now in the Ukraine) into a family of accomplished klezmorim - Leopold’s father was one of twelve brothers, all of whom were musicians - Leopold makes the return to his home and where his family were killed by the Gestapo. Here he visits his father’s grave, but also finds himself reunited with a friend he has not seen for fifty years. Leopold Kozlowski spent most of the war in concentration camps where his music became his inspiration for survival. This is a moving and delightful story, narrated by Yale Strom and featuring several pieces of klezmer music, performed by Leopold Kozlowski and others, including performers from the Polish State Theater and the Yiddish State theater. Includes some black and white footage, stills and archival film footage. In Polish, Yiddish, Russian and English with English subtitles. (Award: Special mention Ecumenical Jury Prize, Berlin Film Festival)

results.title: The Last husky
results.creator_credit: Chris Hilton, Jonathan Chester, National Geographic Society, ABC-TV (Australia) and Aurora Films
results.brief_description: The Last husky records the end of the era of sledge dogs in Antarctica. Featuring the final 600 km expedition of the huskies from Mawson Station, this fascinating program also documents the important contribution made to polar exploration by these hardy working dogs over the last 100 years, but times have changed. In 1991 an international agreement banned huskies from the region. As a result, in November 1992, the Australian huskies set off on an epic four week journey to their new home in Minnesota, U.S.A.

results.title: The Last hurrah
results.brief_description: A trip to the bank to secure a loan backing a major housing project by mayor Frank Skeffington (Spencer Tracy), leads to a complicated and corrupted political campaign. The mayor is met by opposition from two of the towns key figures; Amos Force (John Carradine), publisher of the local paper, and Norman Cass Sr. (Basil Rathbone), one of the cities leading bankers. As a measure of protest they nominate the banker’s incompetent son as acting fire commissioner. In an effort to conceal his son’s ineptness the mayor is granted the loan, but in a cruel twist Norman Cass Sr. financially supports the opposition in the upcoming mayoral election and Skeffington has everything working against his re-election. Also starring Jeffrey Hunter, Diane Foster, Pat O’Brien and James Gleason and based on the novel by Edwin O’Connor.

results.title: The Last house on the left
results.creator_credit: Wes Craven, Sean S. Cunningham and Sean S. Cunningham Films
results.brief_description: Historically significant horror film by Wes Craven, is a rape-revenge drama that is unflinching in its depiction of murder, rape, sadism and violence. Despite the poor acting and cheap production values “Last house on the left” has a visceral impact that imparts a sense of dread and loathing upon the viewer. This film, at once derided for its brutality and yet praised for its daring, soon became a cult classic and was consequently, highly influential upon future horror-genre filmmakers. Along with “The Night of the living dead” (Romero, 1968) this film heralded the golden age of horror, ushering in an era of ‘realistic’ depiction of brutality in the American heartland. Contains graphic images and some scenes may disturb.

results.title: The Last Goon show of all
results.brief_description: For those people who loved listening to The Goons on the radio, this video is definitely for you. For the BBC’s 50th anniversary in 1972,the archives delivered three coffins before a destinguished audience at the Camden Theatre, London. They contained three men of entertainment history. Spike Milligna, the well-known typing error, script-writer and voice of Eccles, Moriarty, Little Jim and Minnie Peter Sellers, alias Major Bloodnok, Bluebottle, and Henry Crun, practising his comeback by whistling a soliloquy from Hamlet. Harry Secombe, bald, toothless, Welsh and weighing 37 stone, the brains and the brawn behind Neddy Seagoon, dressed in a floral cretonne frock. The Goons take their final bow, in their last performance after 12 years of silence. From 1952-1960, The Goon Show spawned a cult of quickfire humour as radios’ most influential clowns, driven by an inspired lunacy which wrenched conventional comedy into a new era. Preserved on video as a lasting tribute to their genius, the combined manic brilliance of Milligan, Sellers and Secombe is as fresh and funny today as it was yesterday.
